comments.commentBody: It's a sign of the silly engineering of the front office that we find ourselves wondering if Marcus Thames is or isn't "invaluable".  If there are two players that answer to that description, one is named Damon and the other Matsui.  We have problems and they are likely to become much more apparent as the season ripens.  We no longer have the best closer in the game, even if we do have the best closer of all time.  As for Joba, he has only two modes of operation: As a strike out machine (rarely) and as a game-loser (no rarely).  As for Thames, the question is not whether he has an adequate arm; the question is whether -- with everyone healthy -- he turns out to be as good as anyone else we might stick in right field.  Is anyone encouraged by the fact that Cervelli and Gardener are the players we're likely to put most of our trust in these days?  And then someone like Thames?  Yes, we all know that Teix and A-Rod will come around; or at least we all believe it.  But Jeter is probably past it and Mariano is getting there.  I say all this as an optimist, tamed by realism.  Thames, Johnson, Granderson @ Co. did not create winners in the past and will not preserve one now.
Was on the road & didn't get to the puzzle til Tuesday.  Wow!  Stunned at all the vitriol.

1) For 3 screens, the maximum number of consecutive cooked ribs is 5, starting first at cm 2 for the first time. For 4, the maximum number of ribs is 9, starting at cm 2. Composite number sized screens give less coverage than any of their factors so optimal screen lengths are always prime.

2) The n-th rib is grilled by all screens with length that divides n. Since factors occur in pairs, this will make an odd number for non-square numbers (since there is no grill of size 1). For square numbers, the square root sized grill is not paired, giving an even number of grills cooking any square numbered rib.

3)
A) If the grills have sizes p_1,...,p_n, the grill pattern repeats with period p_1*...*p_n. So, you will get perfectly matched pieces for a length 2*p_1*...*p_n, or 2*(2*3*5*7)=420 for a four grill snake barbecue.

B) If you allow mirror image pieces to match (so grilled ribs ABC match CBA), then by symmetry a snake of length p_1*...p_n will have all matching pieces except the one in the center. In the case of the four grill barbecue, this would correspond to a snake of length 210, in which Harry got the 3 rib segment 104-105-106.

4)
A) The longest sequence of cooked ribs for a 5 grill snake is 13, for grills the sizes of the first 5 primes 2,3,5,7,11.

B) Assuming that the optimal grill sizes will be the n smallest primes, we can approach this computationally as follows:

Given primes p_1,...,p_k, the associated grill pattern repeats every p_1*...*p_k. Since any other prime q is relatively prime to p_1*...*p_k, on an infinite length snake every possible orientation of grill q relative to grill collection p_1,...,p_k will occur. Therefore we can remove the requirement that all grills start at 0, and reduce the problem to finding relative orientations of the n grills to cover as many integers as possible starting from 1 and moving up.

So, given n grills, we will pick an ordering of our grills. Starting from rib 1, we will pick the next grill and orient it to cover the rib, and move to the next. Every time we reach the next uncooked rib, we will use the next grill, until all the grills are used up.

So, to find the longest sequence of cooked ribs, we look for the ordering of grills that will cook the largest number of consecutive ribs under this algorithm, reducing our search space to n! for n grills, rather than p_1*,...,p_n.

Unfortunately this is still too large to search exhaustively, so I could only compute an upper bound. I found that grills with the sizes of the first 18 primes cover at least 107 consecutive segments, whereas best arrangement of 17 I found covers only 99.

Mid-aged, smart, successful, leader, kid-free, spouse-free-- in actuality, this combination of descriptors is a disturbingly decent statistical predictor of gender.  It would be something of an anomaly if, given the rest of the things Ms. Kagan has in her life list, she also had a hubby and little ones at home.  Something of an anomaly, not a profound anomaly-- I know there are plenty of successful Ms.s who do have.  Still, many studies show that for men, work "success" (variously defined, but usually from position and salary) strongly correlates with marriage and children.  For women it does not, or even slightly anticorrelates.  I recall one study where the numbers were done up for business men and women earning high pay (can't remember the exact definition, but the number of participants was large enough to support conclusions) where 95% of the men had kids but only 45% of the women.  The thing that amazes me about this whole flap is how completely average Ms. Kagan's profile is in this light, and how nobody seems to get that THAT might be the real problem somebody should worry about.  Thank you for pointing to the larger issue.  I've been wondering if someone would.  I wish, for Ms. Kagan's sake, focus could get onto her work.  I've been reminded of an interview I heard a long time ago with a women conductor (symphonic, not train) who confessed that one day she hoped to see a review of one of her performances that didn't describe what she was wearing.
Maybe she just needs a good Yenta?
I refer to myself as "on my own."

Posing questions for the soap opera set?

Do we imagine a single woman or single man of lofty accomplishments ponders, or even cares, whether he or she is viewed as single or unmarried by those who view animal reproduction as an accomplishment?
Sticks and stones, Maureen?

As others point out this whole issue seems irrelevant to Kagan's nomination.

However, I do find it strange that even in "Sex and the City" the four girls are obsessed about finding the right guy and getting married -- Charlotte more so than the rest, but the other three as well to different extents. Whenever we watch the shows on DVD or TV reruns my wife finds it depressing, that even in a story set in New York, among very successful women, the talk is so centered on finding the right guy. Anyway, just an observation.

At least one guy apparently finds her quite desirable and posted an apparently sincere and quite charming ad on Craigslist, followed by some cautious, anonymous comments to a blog:
http://abovethelaw.com...

Quoting his ad:
>...Just send me a signal: mention your love of the Mets in your opening statement before the Senate Judiciary Committee, and I’ll know to send you a dinner date invitation for the first Friday in October. We’ll go for Chinese food at a restaurant better than City Lights....

So we should listen very carefully for that Mets mention. Who says there are no second chances?

I think one can embrace an a-sexual existence rather than resign oneself to it. Millions of women do, very happily.The insistence that a partner of whatever sex is necessary to a full life is patronizing and it smacks a little of small town gossip. We live in a big, rewarding world , ladies, [and gents], and sex is only a small, possibly negligible part of all that it offers. Let us take our heads out of Ms Kagan's bed.

hmmm...were you feeling guilty about that pathetic column you wrote in the voice of joe biden?

or, do you resent being lumped with kagan as an unmarried woman of a certain age?

or, is there nothing else on god's green earth to write about, what with a couple wars raging, oil spilling, wing nuts cracking, etc, except kagan's (non-existent and in any case none of our business) sex life?
At first I thought you were going all Andrew Sullivan on us, Mo, but then I realized that- as usual- it's actually all about YOU. Elena Kagan is just fine.
Ms. Kagan would be a mighty nice catch for some mighty nice guy.  She's got that great grin and she's not a bit frumpy.  Let's not write the ending of her story just yet. Great column, Ms. Dowd.

I can understand the White House. Republicans have been willing to drag everyone and anyone through the mud since the President took office. They have done it with overt, repetitive lying even when their claims have been proven patently false. They've done it with irrational obstructionism and with obvious malice. They've done it with the help of right wing talk radio and Fox news who add lies of their own.
Who can blame the White House for trying to spare Elena Kagan some of what has become standard behavior for Republicans.

What a country. We come way too close to having an airhead as Vice President because of her (alleged) charisma, and now we're casting aspersions at a highly-qualified Supreme Court nominee because she lacks the same.

Another wonderful column by Ms. Dowd. Sadly, too true.
But, Ms. Kagan sounds as though she a lot of fun in addition to achieving the stellar goals she set for herself.
RS & Sue from Melbourne are on target.
Bravos all around!

Oviously, Ms. Dowd is better qulified than any male to comment on this silly phenomenon of 'single' vs. 'unmarried' women. We are making some progress but in this area the double standard of focusing on woman's marital status (or lack of it) is certainly an ugly relic from the past.

As far as I know, it was mentioned that Justice Sauter she, hopefully, will replace, was also 'not married' - a bit of a excentric bachelor with an unkempt backyard. Hardly anyone noticed and I do not recall rumors he was 'gay'.

It is useful to realize that true equality manifests itself also in these seemingly minor issues. Female and male cycles of 'fertility' are different but this is completely irrelevant to qualification of either sex for any job. Actually, because of supposedly longer sexual possibilities for men (augmented now so well by Viagra), there is much more danger they will become the disgusting hypocrites like this congressman being interviewed by his mistress about 'abstinence'.

So, we should shift from an unspoken disdain for 'unmarried women' to a great suspicion of sincerity of married or not married men promoting abstinence for others while happily committing a sin of 'fornication' as it used to be called.

May be difficult, though. Many men, including myself during my weak moments, still believe they are 'superior' to any woman, single unmarried, mother, grandmother, etc.

Your examples - Susan Sarandon, Madonna etc - prove your point.  These strong women refuse to give in to society's antiquated notions of what a woman's "proper role" in marriage is, and so they continue to project their single-woman feminenity without fear of being relegated to "unmarried" status.

Maureen Dowd--This column is all about your own sensitivity to your own status and identity. Kagan is fine; I'm fine with her being fine; and Im fine with myself being single, unmarried, divorced, post-50, a mother, a Catholic, an ex-Catholic, sexy, semi-celibate occasionally--etc.--

So I think the question this particular column begs to have answered is: are you OK with yourself, Mo?

One in nine Americans are gay Maureen?  Where's that statistic come from?  Gays are about 3% of the population.  On the other hand, Justice Kagan can raise her hands and say, "Not that there's anything wrong with that!"  Look, the real issue is whether she will rule within the bounds of the Constitution.  The rest is claptrap.

This is more woe-is-me hyperbole about women getting a raw deal compared with men when they choose not to get married or fail to find a suitable mate. The victimology obsession is wearing a little thin, Maureen. Men who remain unmarried until 50 are looked upon in a similar way - the same initial questions and doubts hover over them, although, with men, it's more a suspicion of eccentricity. Then, after you get to know them, you don't really dwell on it much. Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano is unmarried, yet twice she won re-election to the governorship.

A virtuoso exposure of the phony values that afflict the culture.

It does not end with gender. It extends to race, skin color, sexual preference, religion, wealth, immigration arrival (Mayflower v. Rio Grande), and language accents. A culture dependent upon hypocrisy to promote these phony values has no heart or soul.
Seriously.  You're making too big a deal out of this.  I doubt that it's half as distressing to Kagan as it so clearly is to you.

I agree with you, but what we notice here is how hard it is to get rid of addictions. We as a country, as a world, are addicted to oil, and like any addiction it is very hard to combat, and sometime intervention is needed. We should start thinking of how to treat the oil addiction the same way we think about how to deal with different kinds of addiction. Some ideas on how to get away from addictions:
http://www.pandalous.com...
